The **honey badger**, r, is a monster that appears in [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). Honey badgers resist poison and possess the ability to [tunnel](/wiki/Tunnel "Tunnel"), and are capable of decently powerful bites and claw attacks.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopedia Entry](#Encyclopedia_Entry)

## Generation

In addition to random generation, 1d4 honey badgers may be generated on any level with a [beehive](/wiki/Beehive "Beehive") at level creation.

## Strategy

Honey badger packs can spell doom for any player caught unaware, as they move at the same 12 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") and can dig through walls with ease. They also provide an incentive to reach beehives as soon as you discover them - a honey badger will eat any [royal jelly](/wiki/Royal_jelly "Royal jelly") they can get their grubby little paws on. Their 0 AC and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") also make them much harder to dispatch and give them a stellar defense against [killer bees](/wiki/Killer_bee "Killer bee"), which they will attack on sight.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Honey badger](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honey_badger "wikipedia:Honey badger")***

The honey badger, *mellivora capensis*, is a mammal found in Africa, Southwest Asia and the Indian subcontinent. It is considered a member of the weasel family, and obtains a large part of its food by digging it out of burrows. Honey badgers are best known for their tendency to raid beehives in search of both bee larvae and honey, as well as their surprising viciousness against other predators such as lion cubs and black mambas. These traits have made honey badgers a popular animal among Internet users as early as 2008.

## Encyclopedia Entry

The Honey badger (or ratel) is a tenacious small carnivore that  
has a reputation for being, pound for pound, Africa's most fearless  
animal despite its small size. It is even listed as the "most  
fearless animal in the world" in the Guinness Book of Records.  
  
Honey badgers are reputed to go for the scrotum when attacking large  
animals. The first published record of this behaviour was a  
circumstantial account by Stevenson-Hamilton (1947) where a badger  
reportedly castrated an adult Buffalo. Other animals alleged to have  
been emasculated by honey badgers include wildebeest, waterbuck, kudu,  
zebra and man. This has also been reported by other African tribes,  
but no direct evidence exists to support this behaviour.

Honey badger

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
r honey badger (No tile)
Difficulty 12
Attacks Bite 2d6, Claw 2d8
r honey badger (No tile)
Difficulty 12
Attacks

Bite 2d6, Claw 2d8

Base level 10
Base experience 158
Speed 12
Base AC 0
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 150
Nutritional value 100
Size Small
Resistances poison
Resistances conveyed None

A honey badger:

  • can tunnel through walls.
  • has no hands.
  • is an animal.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is strong.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference EvilHack - monst.c, line 1056

Generation

They also provide an incentive to reach beehives as soon as you discover them - a honey badger will eat any royal jelly they can get their grubby little paws on. Their 0 AC and poison resistance also make them much harder to dispatch and give them a stellar defense against killer bees, which they will attack on sight.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Honey badger

The honey badger, mellivora capensis, is a mammal found in Africa, Southwest Asia and the Indian subcontinent. It is considered a member of the weasel family, and obtains a large part of its food by digging it out of burrows. Honey badgers are best known for their tendency to raid beehives in search of both bee larvae and honey, as well as their surprising viciousness against other predators such as lion cubs and black mambas. These traits have made honey badgers a popular animal among Internet users as early as 2008.

Encyclopedia Entry

The Honey badger (or ratel) is a tenacious small carnivore that
has a reputation for being, pound for pound, Africa's most fearless
animal despite its small size. It is even listed as the "most
fearless animal in the world" in the Guinness Book of Records.

Honey badgers are reputed to go for the scrotum when attacking large
animals. The first published record of this behaviour was a
circumstantial account by Stevenson-Hamilton (1947) where a badger
reportedly castrated an adult Buffalo. Other animals alleged to have
been emasculated by honey badgers include wildebeest, waterbuck, kudu,
zebra and man. This has also been reported by other African tribes,
but no direct evidence exists to support this behaviour.

The '''honey badger''', {{black|r}}, is a monster that appears in [[EvilHack]] and [[Hack'EM]]. Honey badgers resist poison and possess the ability to [[tunnel]], and are capable of decently powerful bites and claw attacks.

==Generation==
In addition to random generation, 1d4 honey badgers may be generated on any level with a [[beehive]] at level creation.

==Strategy==
Honey badger packs can spell doom for any player caught unaware, as they move at the same 12 [[speed]] and can dig through walls with ease. They also provide an incentive to reach beehives as soon as you discover them - a honey badger will eat any [[royal jelly]] they can get their grubby little paws on. Their 0 AC and [[poison resistance]] also make them much harder to dispatch and give them a stellar defense against [[killer bee]]s, which they will attack on sight.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Honey badger}}
The honey badger, ''mellivora capensis'', is a mammal found in Africa, Southwest Asia and the Indian subcontinent. It is considered a member of the weasel family, and obtains a large part of its food by digging it out of burrows. Honey badgers are best known for their tendency to raid beehives in search of both bee larvae and honey, as well as their surprising viciousness against other predators such as lion cubs and black mambas. These traits have made honey badgers a popular animal among Internet users as early as 2008.

==Encyclopedia Entry==

	has a reputation for being, pound for pound, Africa's most fearless
	animal despite its small size.  It is even listed as the "most

	Honey badgers are reputed to go for the scrotum when attacking large

	but no direct evidence exists to support this behaviour.
